chapter.htmlHeader: How common is it?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• The prevalence of life-limiting conditions in children in England is both rising and higher than previously estimated and is more than double previous prevalence estimates [Fraser, 2015].
  • It is estimated that there are around 49,000 children living with life-limiting conditions in the UK [Fraser, 2011].  
  • Overall prevalence in people aged 0–19 years has increased from 25 per 10,000 in 2000/01 to 32 per 10,000 population in 2009/10, with prevalence highest in children aged under 1 year (126 per 10,000) [Fraser, 2011].  
    • Prevalence has increased in all age groups but is most marked in those aged 16-19 years where there was a 44.8% increase over the 10 years. Prevalence increased by:
      • 37.9% in children aged 11–15 years.  
      • 31.9% in children aged 6–10 years.
      • 17.1% in children aged 1–5 years.
      • 7·7% in children aged under 1 year. 
    • The increased prevalence in males (35.2%, 95% CI 34.7–35.7) is significantly higher than in females (29.2%, 95% CI 28.8–29.6).
    • Prevalence also varies with:
      • Ethnicity — the highest prevalence is in people of South Asian origin (47.6 per 10,000, 95% CI 46.8 to 48.4), the Black population (41.5 per 10,000, 95% CI 39.5 to 43.5) and the Chinese and other population (30.7 per 10,000, 95% CI 29.4 to 32.0). These were significantly higher compared to the White population (27.0 per 10,000, 95% CI 26.7, 27.3).
      • Deprivation — the prevalence in each deprivation category over time shows an inverse J-shaped relationship with deprivation, with the highest prevalence in the most deprived category (category 1) and the lowest in the second most affluent group (category 4).
      • Geographical location — the North East, North West, West Midlands and London have a higher prevalence than the South West, Yorkshire and Humber and the East Midlands.
  • In England in 2017, there were around 3,000 child deaths due to medical conditions, of which 2,351 of these were due to a known life-limiting condition or a neonatal death [TSL, 2018].
